Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: This morning, as I sipped my coffee, my granddaughter called, her voice trembling with uncertainty. She was about to start her first job and wanted to talk, hoping for some guidance. I could hear the hope in her words, the way she trusted me to help her make sense of this new chapter. I wanted to be there for her, to listen and share what I’ve learned over the years. But at the same time, I remembered that today was my only chance to drive across town and pick up my ID from home—without it, I wouldn’t be able to vote tomorrow. The polls would still be open, but I wouldn’t have another opportunity to get my ID. My granddaughter needed me now, but so did my civic duty. I felt torn, the weight of both responsibilities pressing on me, each demanding my presence in a different place. My heart ached as I tried to decide which role to honor in this moment, knowing that either choice meant letting someone—or something—down.
